A older brother, gentle with and protective of: ALEJANDRO MURIETTA, eight. Despite his age, Alejandro is natural leader of the two, although neither knows it. He’s not going to come.
Should we move closer? (CONTINUED)

Hooligans! What do you think you're doing? Get out of here! An UNDERTAKER glares in at them, holding up a flap of can wears a black suit as severe as his expression. It's his evidenced by the three empty coffins inside.
We should move closer! He slices the canvas, and the two dive out into the squar
The boys scramble around and among the legs of onlookers, closer to the semi-circle.
Where is he?
I don't see him.
He's got to come. He’s very brave. On all fours, they slip past a group of UNIFORMED SOLDIER

Yes, but he’s also very smart. [The boys crawl past a MAN in ROUGH HOODED CLOAK, his san visible -- He reaches out and grabs them (gently) by the ears. It is FELIPE, an out-of-place scowl on his round, jovial face.
(horrified) Fray Felipe!

Do you suppose you're parents -- God- rest-their-souls -- would approve of you two being here? (leans closer; worried) There's going to be trouble. Get back to the mission -- now! He gives them a little push. Abashed, they move away, awa Felipe watching them. But as soon as he turns away -- (CONTINUED)

Alejandro grabs Joaquin, yanks him down. Back on all four leading, they crawl back through the crowd. Suddenly, Ale cut off, bumping into the knees of a MAN in a ROUGH HOODE Sure he's caught, he looks down --] Beneath the monk's robe are SHINY BLACK BOOTS WITH SILVER And the SILVER TIP of a SCABBARD. ?Alejandro's eyes go wide. He looks up -- ANGLE - LOOKING UP: Beneath the monk's hood, a mask, a da mustache, the flash of a smile. It's ZORRO. He puts a fin his lips: 'Shhh.' Alejandro wheels, scrambles back to Joaquin.
Joaquin! He's here! He's here!
Zorro's here?

(a finger to his lips, a la Zorro) SHHHH! He's right over there -- [He points -- ?The monk's robe lies discarded on the ground. ] Alejandro looks around in wonder, amazed at the disappear Joaquin grabs his hand, heads for a ladder.

C'mon! Alejandro is dragged along; he barely avoids running into DON LUIZ, an older man, tall and thin, with an elegant go pushes through the crowd, reaches the entrance to the Vic Building. Soldiers meet him with a challenge.
Don Luiz. The Viceroy sent for me.

Don Luiz moves down a hallway, his face pale, eyes taking activity. He dodges servants as they rush past, roll up t hurriedly pack household items, etc. Soldiers carry heavy out, moving with a sense of urgency.
The door is ajar. Don Luiz steps into the study, which ha cleared out quickly. Shelves emptied, drawers left open. scattered about. (CONTINUED)

A balcony opens off the room. Looking out over the square darkly handsome man with the eyes of a snake. He wears an understated military uniform, and stands utterly still. T RAFAEL MONTERO, Viceroy of Alta California.
I hoped it wasn't true. You're returning to Spain ..?
I am the Spanish Viceroy, after all - - and California is no longer part of Spain. (bitter) Santa Anna's troops are already on their way to take control of the presidio.]
[The Dons are worried.] How will we fare under Mexico? Ruled by peasants
Who will squander this land the same way Spain has. California is richer than anyone can imagine (smiles) Anyone but me. One day, Don Luiz, I will return. And all of our plans will see fruition.
Know that we will always remain loyal to you. And will strive to keep California at least ... a little civilized.
A hard thing, in this land of savages. He catches the eye of the firing SQUAD LEADER.
Begin the execution! +IN THE SQUARE: Alejandro and Joaquin scramble across a r Below them, the Squad Leader draws his sword.
Preparén! (he raises his sword) Apuntén! The crowd is still. Alejandro and Joaquin search for Zorr prisoners stand straight, meeting death with honor. (CONTINUED)
The Squad Leader is about to slash his arm down --

Disparen! Fingers tighten on triggers -- ?with a CRACK the fall of a whip wraps around one of the barrels -- and yanks it sideways, into the next, sending sideways, and so on, like dominoes, so that all the rifle pointed at the SQUAD LEADER --
No disparen! No disparen -- Too late -- the soldiers FIRE. The Squad Leader crumples The whip-wielder leaps nimbly into the square: an apparit black, sword drawn. Alejandro spots him first --
Zorro! The crowd sees him. People point; a cry rises up:

Zorro reaches the prisoners. Three quick slashes free the Several of the soldiers reload. Others draw their swords, Zorro -- Zorro fights with graceful economy, anticipating all atta [As the freed prisoners make their escape, Felipe upends barrels.] The barrels roll free, blocking and tripping so The CROWD has erupted; some of the peasants try to block soldiers, who club them down -- Zorro parries two soldiers' swords into a wheel of the ov wagon, spins the wheel; their swords are wrenched away.
Trust Zorro to spoil a good execution.
I was counting on it. He takes a candle from a sconce, light a torch strapped t balcony rail. The torch FLARES to life -- ON ALEJANDRO AND JOAQUIN, as they look up, see the signal (CONTINUED)
?-- as do several SOLDIERS, who emerge onto the wood balc below the boys, taking up positions to fire at Zorro.
Look!

An ambush! We’ve got to warn Zorro - Alejandro is ahead of him. There's a large, loose brick o roof's edge. He strains to shove it off. Joaquin joins hi The stone SMASHES down on the soldiers, taking them out. Zorro turns at the noise, sees the soldiers -- then spots Other soldiers start firing at him. Zorro dives away, SMA through the door of a building -- Alejandro and Joaquin peer over the roof's edge. Like the they wait for Zorro to reappear -- Black-gloved hands drop onto their shoulders. They spin - It is Zorro. He has almost magically appeared behind them
My thanks to you, gentlemen. He removes a MEDALLION from around his neck. It has an in design: several circles within the large circle, with var of radii intersecting.
Here. A symbol of my gratitude. But you’1l have to share it. He holds it. It's a ceremonious moment. The Medallion gle Alejandro reaches for it, but too late -- Joaquin takes i

Now -- if you’1l excuse me And he steps off the roof, onto an overhang, leaps to a c onto -- MONTERO'S BALCONY. Zorro holds his blade on Montero, who flinch. Behind him, Don Luiz fades back, fingering his ow
You were willing to kill those men to trap me. (CONTINUED)
I'd have killed a hundred men -- if I could be sure that one of them was you.

You should have learned by now. No innocent will die as long as I'm alive to rescue them. Three men. Three cuts. Lightning-quick, he makes THREE QUICK CUTS on Montero's n Montero slaps a hand up, covering them.

A souvenir of your days in California. (beat ) Good-bye, Montero. And good riddance. He whistles -- ?A HUGE BLACK STALLION gallops into the square. Zorro lea from the balcony onto its back. Soldiers scramble as Zorr through them, up a flight of exterior stairs -- Silhouetted against the setting sun low on the horizon, Z horseback leaps from rooftop to rooftop, then is gone. ON ALEJANDRO AND JOAQUIN, watch in awe as he disappears. feeling of ceremony, Joaquin lifts the medallion, drapes his neck. Alejandro reaches out to touch it, lightly, rev ON THE BALCONY OVERLOOKING THE SQUARE. Montero lowers his his neck. On the palm is the bloody IMPRINT of a backward mirroring the one on his neck. Montero clenches his hand into a bloody fist.
A waterfall cascades over stone. Zorro rides up, dismount smoothly. Removes the horse's tack and saddle, pets him.
There you go, Tornado. Take the rest of the night off. Tornado snorts, gallops away. Saddle over his shoulder, Z climbs a path, disappears behind the waterfall --
A large GRANDFATHER CLOCK swings aside on oiled hinges. I secret doorway, cave wall visible beyond. DIEGO DE LA VEG out. Mid-thirties, a dashing and handsome man.
Diego steps in quietly. A striking view through the windo cliffs above the moonlit ocean. A large stand of manzanit outside. But Diego's eyes are on the small occupant of a beneath the window sill--

Hello, darling Elena. Do you want to hear what your father did tonight? It is quite the hair-raising adventure -- J In the crib is ELENA DE LA VEGA, almost two. A sleeping a with funny-looking spiky hair. Diego dotes on her
(re: her hair) Oh, you've heard it already?

She doesn't understand a word you say. She just likes the sound of your voice. [Standing in the doorway is ESPERANZA. She wears a simple accented by a yellow pafuelo -- a full-length silk scarf. grows up to resemble her mother at all (and she will), sh break a thousand hearts. Diego slips an arm around Espera waist.
Someday she'll listen to my stories that's all I ask.
Exposed oak beams. Elegant furniture and filled bookshelv by candlelight. Diego and Elena enter.
All I ask is you be around to tell them. More fear is in her tone than she intended. Diego notes i
Esperanza ... She gestures ‘one moment.' Shuts her eyes, gathering hers looks at Diego, in control of her fear now.
Diego ... I love you ... and I love you for what you do. But ... I can smell the gunsmoke on you. (wryly) And you're not getting any younger -- (CONTINUED)
(pulls her close) I assure you ... My bones aren't brittle yet.
Not all of them, anyway. A passionate kiss -- [] Suddenly the door CRASHES open, a full weight behind it. Other SOLDIERS spill in behind him
Madre de Dios -- Montero strides in. A blood-stained bandage is around his
Viceroy -- this is my home. what do you want here? (re: the bandage) Did you cut yourself shaving? MONTERO. Glib as ever, de la Vega. I have come to settle things between us.
There is nothing between us.
You are a betrayer, de la Vega. You have stood against me -- and your fellow Dons -- for as long as I can remember.
Only when you were wrong. Which has been as long as I can remember.
You've secretly funded General Santa Anna and his craven rebels -- Don't deny it! Montero regards Diego coldly.
You have many powerful friends, in Spain as well as Mexico. But none will seek revenge for the death of Zorro. Esperanza and Diego stare at him. And then -- they laugh. (CONTINUED)
Believe me, Rafaél -- if he were Zorro, I'd be the first to know.
No, actually, I would -- Montero stares at Esperanza. He shakes his head.
You chose badly, Esperanza. You gave your love to the wrong man. Her eyes blaze. She returns his gaze levelly.
There was never any choice to make. Diego steps between them. Glares at Montero.
I think you're dizzy, Montero. From loss of blood, perhaps?

For fifteen years Zorro has been a thorn in my side. I've always suspected you, de la Vega. I just never had any proof. From beneath his jacket he produces a black cape and mask imitations of Zorro's. Holds them up to a SERGEANT.
Find these somewhere. (nods his head) And kill him. A soldier grabs for Diego. Diego evades him, slides the s the soldier's belt. SLAMS the soldier hard into a wall.
Now, you choose, Montero: Leave my house. Or ... (a deadly smile) Actually, there's no choice there, either.
Everyone knows that Diego de la Vega has no affection for the fight. He attacks, engaging Diego -- who is, of course, Zorro. M smiles at Diego's skill. (CONTINUED)
You really are Zorro, aren't you?

Affection and ability are two different things. This time Diego attacks, forcing Montero back. A soldier, sword drawn, moves to attack Diego's back -- Esperanza grabs a broom and trips him. The Sergeant is dr pistol; Esperanza shoves the bristles into his face, knoc back, then smacks the pistol away. A second soldier moves toward Diego and Montero, who cont duel, blades FLASHING in candlelight. A third soldier moves toward Diego -- ?The Sergeant finds his lost pistol, takes aim at Diego - ?Esperanza leaps to defend Diego from the third soldier - ?The Sergeant FIRES -- The SHOT freezes the room. The next sound is --

Diego and Montero watch in horror as she crumples to the The Sergeant, aghast, still holds the smoking pistol. As one, Diego and Montero lunge, their blades piercing th Sergeant's heart. The Sergeant falls back against a stand candelabra. It topples, setting curtains ABLAZE.
Diego drops his sword, leaps to Esperanza. He cradles her arms, her blood staining his shirt.
Oh, Esperanza ... Esperanza ... Montero moves closer, stands over him, staring down in ho Esperanza. He is genuinely stricken, oblivious to the fla growing around them.
(soft; to himself) You deserved better. You would have loved to see Spain. A BURNING BEAM CRASHES down, separating the two men. Dieg himself back as FLAMES ERUPT HIGHER --
Elena! (CONTINUED)
He scrambles toward her room. WOOD CREAKS -- ?-- Diego turns as a section of WALL FALLS INWARD. He thr his arms in defense --

Diego lands hard; he comes to slowly. Firelight illumines He raises his hands -- they are chained. He is in a cage wagon, with several other prisoners. His eyes focus, and -- through the bars he sees his hacienda ENGULFED IN FLAM
Elena! ELENA!
She's still inside. Diego snaps a look at him, his rage building. He rattles bars, lets loose an almost animal howl --
Montero! DAMN YOU TO HELL, MONTERO! I will find you and kill you -- The Soldier RINGS his sword off the bars.

Shut up. The Viceroy didn't get out either. (to the driver) Take him away! You'll rot in the dungeons at Talamantes, de la Vega. You'll die there. The wagon starts forward with a jerk. Diego stares at the HACIENDA. He collapses back, draws his knees up to his ch defeated. Rain begins to fall.
I... am dead all ready. (a whisper) Esperanza ... Elena The Soldier watches the wagon disappear. From the Hacienda comes the sound of the ROOF COLLAPSING.
A FIGURE appears, runs OUT OF THE FLAMES. Cloaked in a sm carpet. Soldiers gather round him -- (CONTINUED)
The figure throws back the carpet from his face, leaves i around him like a cape. It is MONTERO.
Viceroy! You're all right -- ?
Where's de la Vega?
Gone -- to Talamantes. With the others. Montero is livid. This is not what he intended.
No! Get him back here! I'll kill him -- A SCOUT steps forward.
No time, sir. There are Mexican troops just over the hills. They'll see the fire --
Damn! Montero stares in the direction Diego's wagon went. Consi course of action.
Damn him. Let's go. There comes the soft sound of a BABY CRYING. Montero thro carpet all the way off -- In his arms is ELENA. He cradles her, protecting her from

Shh, nifia. Shh. I'll take care of you. (pulls her close) You should have been mine, and now you are. The rain POURS down, extinguishing the FLAMES of the burn hacienda. Smoke pours across the huge, full moon.

Handsome despite unkempt hair and shaggy beard. Their hands apparently tie them, they are prisoners of -- THREE-FINGERED JACK, a powerfully-built man, the rough lo bounty hunter. CLOSE ON: A POSTER: 'WANTED: THE MURIETTA BROTHERS.' Pass drawings of Joaquin and Alejandro. The poster is being nailed to a post by CORPORAL LOPEZ, a soldier. He is watched by the OWNER, his little GIRL, an and a FARMER. Three SOLDIERS loiter, guarding a horse-drawn wagon. Thei drink, and the soldiers help themselves to produce -- to disgust.
The army should be capturing these bandits -- instead of just nailing up wanted posters. People have been disappearing --] (worried) I haven't seen Jose Gonzales in weeks.
He's right. There are more and more disaparecidos all the time. Farmers Indians -- even woman and children. No one's safe.
(shrugs) A few peasants disappear, what does it matter? These Muriettas actually dare to rob cabelleros and soldiers.
The only ones with any money. (CONTINUED)
Zorro could capture them. Zorro could find the disappeared ones].
Who's Zorro? Lopez rolls his eyes.
You peasants. Have to have your little stories about Zorro. He picks up a tomato lazily, bites into it.
(to the girl) Zorro was a great man -- a champion. He protected us. He would stop the disappearances, if he were here.
He would make people pay for the food they ate. Lopez backhands him -- suddenly and violently.
These are taxes. To pay the soldiers who do protect you. He kneels beside the Girl, addresses her like a kindly un

I'll tell you who Zorro was. Zorro was a crazy man who wore a mask. Do you know what that makes him? A bandit. And if he showed himself around here, we'd treat him just like any other bandit. (a tomato-red smile) We'd hunt him down and kill him.

Or get someone to do it for you. He points. Everyone looks where he's pointing: At JACK, l ALEJANDRO and JOAQUIN, coming up the road. The soldiers raise their rifles warily. Lopez gestures fo wait as Jack draws near.
I heard soldiers came through here every week. I think I got some people you want to meet. (CONTINUED)
(looking at the poster) It's them! It's the Murietta brothers. Lopez examines the brothers. Squints at the poster. Jack dismounts, crowds forward, everyone trying to see the pos
So -- how much is the reward? (Lopez glares at him) Just asking.
(boastful) Well, these soldiers are delivering the army payroll. That sounds about right.
Ha. The reward's two hundred pesos.
(aghast ) Two hundred pesos? For each of us? Joaquin reaches up, tears down the poster, looks at it
For both of us!
That's insulting! (to Jack) If I were you, I wouldn't accept it. You worked too hard to catch us. Lopez's eyes widen -- he finally notices that Joaquin's h free, holding the poster. He points --

Joaquin! Down! (CONTINUED)

Joaquin drops to his knees. The rope between them is taut Alejandro keeps a grip on the rope, leaving some slack ar neck -- but Joaquin doesn't. Hey! Joaquin grabs the rifle barrel, and yanks it away -- then like a bat, clocking the soldier. It's over in seconds, and Lopez is still staring down Jac barrel. The onlookers are a little stunned by it all.
(rubbing his throat) Damn it, Alejandro -- next time, warn me. [Alejandro doesn't look up. He's too busy going through t unconscious soldiers' pockets. ]
Next time. Jack, gun still on Lopez, picks up the Wanted Poster.

Look at this. I'm not on here. (to Lopez) I'm Three-Fingered Jack. How hard is it to remember that? (holds up his hand) Three fingers! See? Three-Fingered Jack! [Now Alejandro's loading food into a basket as he makes t turn their pockets inside-out. He's not impressed. ]

The Old Man brings Joaquin his sword. Joaquin takes it, m swipes.
Are you supposed to be Zorro?
(flattered) You think I look like Zorro?
No. [Joaquin deflates. Alejandro chuckles, tosses the basket into the wagon, climbs on.]
Zorro wasn't a bandit. He just used to wear a medallion like yours, that's all.
Go away. He climbs up on the wagon beside Alejandro.
Let's get out of here. He tries to ignore Alejandro's grin. Alejandro flicks the The wagon moves.
Captain Love will have your heads for this. Jack still has his gun on Lopez. He raises his hand -- Lo back -- but Jack just displays his fingers.
Remember: Three-Fingered Jack.
I'll remember. He mounts his horse, smiles 'thank you.' Waves daintily, horse. Follows the wagon away, leaving behind unconscious excited onlookers, and an angry Lopez.

We're rich. (to Joaquin) We can keep it, right?
Half. Half we give to the mission.
Don't start that! What've they ever done for us?
Fray Felipe raised us -- taught us --
And we turned out so well. That gold is ours! We should just take it and run!
Dammit, Alejandro --]
This isn't some army payroll. This is something else -- something big. They'll hunt us down. We'll just be three more disaparecidos.
Zorro would never have run away --
Look around, Joaquin! Do any of us look like Zorro? (pointed) No! Joaquin regards him. Then puts a hand on his shoulder
So we ride to the mission. In honor of Zorro. Alejandro looks at him; the point is settled. Alejandro t bar of gold in his hands; sunlight FLARES off of it --  20.

Slashes of light shine down through the deck. SWORDS CRAS ?Two figures duel with classic small swords. One is an OL SALT, gray and grizzled but still spry. The other one is with long hair, tied back. They duel amongst the boxes of cargo. The Old Salt feints lunges -- and FREEZES. His opponent's blade is aimed dire his heart. He looks up at -- ELENA. Even wearing man's clothes she is breathtaking. My father is an expert swordsman.
Then how come you go to old sailors for your lessons. Old sailors ... and Spanish Gypsies. (her surprise confirms it) Thought I knew the style.

My father would say ... it is improper for a lady to learn the sword. He is a very proper man. (sighs; troubled) And I don't think I'm the proper daughter he deserves. Suddenly the hatch opens; light floods in.
Elena! Elena and Old Salt exchange shocked glances.
I can't imagine what she'd be doing in the hold.

Neither can I -- but I can't find her anywhere else. [Elena makes a decision. Tosses the Old Salt her sword, g traveling cloak -- and wriggles out through a porthole. ] The Old Salt strikes a nonchalant pose -- realizes he sti the swords. We are looking for Don Montero's daughter. Have you seen her?
Down here? Not unless she's got a taste for rats. Montero looks in distastefully from the top of the stairw
Hardly. She is a refined and delicate lady.
[Montero, the Captain and the Old Salt emerge from the ho Old Salt spots Elena, climbing over the seaward rail. She him with her eyes. He turns so that the Captain and Monte are to her.]
I don't want to be a Jonah -- but could she have...? (jerks his head overboard)
(to the Captain) If she has fallen overboard, I will hold you and your crew responsible --
Who's fallen overboard, father? They turn. Elena stands there, the traveling cloak concea attire.
I was afraid you had --
You were looking for me? Why? Something exciting, I hope. He smiles at her enthusiasm. He offers her his arm.
Something you've never seen before.
Montero and Elena are at the rail, his hands over her eye (CONTINUED)
California. He uncovers her eyes. Elena gasps. Across the white-cappe the golden hills move past.
We're there?
Our new home. She hugs Montero, her eyes still taking in the sight.
All my life, it seems, I've dreamed of California.
Don Montero ... your boat is ready. But I tell you again ... this delay will put the tides against us.
No matter. I must go ashore.
Why, Father? What's wrong?
Nothing, dear. Nothing that need concern you. Montero looks away, out across the water, lost in thought

Guard! His voice is just a raw croak. Ordaz looks up.

who?

Me. He whips the rope belt from his pants, loops it around th neck, yanks his head into the bars with a CLANG. Ordaz fi Diego CLANGS him again. And again. Ordaz slumps, unconscious.
